docs.lead_paragraph: In April and May of 1994, Federal investigators say, a chiropractor, William Lindemann, claimed that on a half-dozen occasions his staff had provided ''chiropractic adjustment'' to a patient named Anthony Liberatore at one of the doctor's Brooklyn offices. But during those months, Mr. Liberatore was in no position to be treated in any chiropractic office -- he was in jail awaiting trial on a murder charge.

headline.main: Chiropractor Is Indicted In Fraud Case

docs.abstract: Dr William Lindemann, chiropractor, is named in Federal indictment on fraud charges in what officials say is first arrest resulting from investigation into insurance fraud schemes that they believe includes participation by people linked to organized crime; inquiry was started by information provided by two former Mafia figures now cooperating with Govt (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: FOR Joan Winer Brown, the medical setbacks began in August 1984, when a stray bullet came barreling into her Bronx home, shattering an arm bone. The next year, Ms. Brown's husband, Thomas, underwent a heart transplant. And two years later, he developed the lymphoma that would eventually kill him.

headline.main: Conquering Cancer, but Depleting Her Savings

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Daniel Coben (letter, Nov. 9) implies that cost-cutting insurance companies' use of underqualified professionals is the reason for reprehensible ''patient manipulation and memory fabrication.'' Not really. The therapists in the Chicago malpractice lawsuit are state-licensed psychiatrists, and the hospital is a reputable one. Insurance payments for the patients were in the millions.
docs.abstract: Letter from Karen Johnson prompted by Daniel Coben's Nov 9 letter scores professional organizations for their reluctance to establish responsible standards of mental health care (S)
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Daniel Coben (letter, Nov. 9) implies that cost-cutting insurance companies' use of underqualified professionals is the reason for reprehensible ''patient manipulation and memory fabrication.'' Not really. The therapists in the...

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Your Nov. 12 letters on acupuncture note that we have not, by Western standards, adequately explained why it works. I am a rheumatologist and have used acupuncture and traditional medicine side by side for more than a decade. I can see that medical science is made uneasy by a discipline that seeks to ''balance'' and alleviate symptoms rather than cure the disease.
docs.abstract: Dr Steven D Meed letter comments on Nov 12 letters on acupuncture; says doctors and insurers should be more open to the treatment, which helps many patients (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Eddie Arcaro, the master of thoroughbred racing for 31 years as America's premier jockey, who five times won the Kentucky Derby and twice swept the Triple Crown, died yesterday at his home in Miami. He was 81. Arcaro died after a long illness, according to his wife, Vera.

headline.main: Eddie Arcaro, Only Jockey to Win Racing's Triple Crown Twice, Is Dead at 81

docs.abstract: Eddie Arcaro, premier jockey who five times won the Kentucky Derby and twice swept the Triple Crown, dies at age 81; photo (M)
